item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
In a dynamic object-oriented language like Ruby, there are a lot of potential sources for whatever method you're calling. Sometimes you need to know which one you're using; for instance, to check whether you've got a scoping issue or to verify you're looking at the right page in an API's documentation.

method :methodname

This is where Object#method comes in handy. It take a symbol corresponding to the name of a method available to self, and returns a Method object. The object has much to reveal about it origins. class Example def hello_world 'hello' end puts self.new.method :hello_world # # end puts Example.new.method :hello_world # # puts [].method :each # # def nothing_much() end method :nothing_much puts method :method # In the first and last examples, the parentheses indicate the method originates in a module. So, nil? is Object#nil? and was included in Object by the Kernel module.

Poking at Method objects

The Method

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
"Consulting is a service business, not "a cash game." It's my opinion that the best consultants enjoy providing that service, not just banging out code for money. They want to be a partner in the client's business, not just an implementer of a spec. From the client's perspective, if it's about money, not pride or quality or results, for the consultancy, they might as well pick a cheaper overseas firm.

It is very satisfying to help a company get off the ground and equally heartbreaking to work with clients who go out of business. There's a lot of emotional investment that goes into working on behalf of startups."

Yep. And I'll add that it's true too when the client isn't a startup.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Last weekend, I volunteered as a coach for the first RailsGirls workshop in the U.S. Exciting! Among the many reasons to look forward to it: a chance to see Tokaido in action. There's nothing like a random collection of Macs to stress test an approach for getting Ruby 1.9.* to consistently install smoothly in the hands of novices. Boy did this one go smoothly. And fast, in comparison to the XCode Commandline Tools method. The only glitch was experienced by some of the Lion users: the bash script would declare installation a success and yet their terminal would still only find system Ruby and system gems. Even after opening a new tab, the shell seemed to have no awareness of Tokaido's existence. Kenneth Reitz, author of oxs-gcc-installer, peeked over some shoulders and realized that the problem was that the script writes to ~/.profile. His fix was easy: echo "source ~/.profile" >> ~/.bash_profile Then open yet another tab. Voila. So that got me curious. It's a pain to keep straight .profile vs .bash_profile vs. .bashrc (not to mention /etc/profile, and ~/.MacOSX/environment.plist, oy vey!). So it wasn't immediately obvious why .bash_profile was needed. If it doesn't exist, shouldn't OSX source ~/.profile anyway?

item.title: RailsBridge & RailsGirls: chocolate & peanut butter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Last week I had the privilege of being a coach for the first U.S. workshop for RailsGirls. RailsGirls was co-founded in Finland by Linda Liukas after she attended a RailsBridge workshop in San Francisco. At first glance, the mission, format, and curricula of the two look pretty similar. Yet the details show how RailsGirls has evolved into its own unique thing. The experiences do indeed differ. First the similarities:
  • Educational outreach focused on bringing more women into programming and their local Ruby/Rails developer communities.
  • Nearly all students are female; some workshops also have a few men.
  • Workshops are provided entirely free, with all expenses covered by sponsoring companies (supplemented occasionally other sources), hosted at companies or conferences that are connected to the Ruby/Rails scene, and staffed entirely by volunteers from the community.
  • The workshop starts on Friday evening with everyone getting their laptops setup with all the software you'll need. Then on Saturday, it's a full day of education. Finally, the day winds down with an afterparty.
RailsBridge is older, and the one I know best -- as observer, student, instructor, and these days as a workshop organizer. RailsGirls (which was inspired by Railsbridge) has similar mission, and relatively similar format using a wholly different curriculum. Its co-founder, Linda Liukas, just moved to New York. No doubt she will be announcing a workshop there soon. But I bet it wouldn't hurt to put in a formal offer/request through their website. Both organizations' workshops bring something valuable to any effort at addressing underrepresentation of women. RailsGirls is aimed at beginners exclusively, and tries to introduce concepts from the bigger picture of development lifecycle. RailsBridge workshops provide levels from novice to advanced, and the curriculum is more focused on Ruby and Rails than the broad range of associated professions/technologies. So they're addressing different scopes, albeit with a fair chunk of overlap. Renee De Voursney, who previously organized a RailsBridge workshop in Seattle, is putting on a RailsBridge workshop next week in Berlin. The event is organized/sponsored by RailsGirls Berlin. The workshop schedule appears to be a hybrid. Meanwhile, Daniel Choi is considering how to do a blended curriculum for his upcoming workshop in Boston too. One of the organizers for that event also previously organized a RailsBridge event there. Reese's Peanut Butter Cups used to have an ad campaign that fits well here. Chocolate and peanut butter do make each other taste better. With RailsBridge currently expanding to more European cities and RailsGirls poised to arrive all over the U.S. in coming months, I think we'll see more initiatives like this as local Ruby communities discover both opportunities exist. It'll be interesting to see where this leads next. I'm hoping to glean some lessons from both Renee, Liana, and Daniel; and ultimately do more of that experimentation. Meanwhile, I'm organizing another RailsBridge workshop next month and will be organizing workshop #2 for RailsGirls SF. Stay tuned.

item.title: I recently launched CallbackWomen, a Twitter feed devoted to connecting tech conferences that are seeking...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I recently launched CallbackWomen, a Twitter feed devoted to connecting tech conferences that are seeking programmers as speakers, with the code women who are speakers are seeking opportunity.

CallbackWomen follows more than 150 conferences, and has already shared a long list of open CFPs. (Many of which are still open right now, by the way...)

What you can do:

* Encourage conference organizers to reach out directly to CallbackWomen, with CFP announcements. Many have found it particularly valuable to explicitly state their commitment to bringing in more proposals from women.

* Follow the CallbackWomen feed to spot new opportunities for you to propose talks. 

* Browse the Follows list to discover interesting conferences that you haven't heard about yet.

* Suggest more conferences for CallbackWomen to Follow. (Curatorial note: limited to conferences which are primarily focused on programming topic and seek programmers as speakers.  The overall universe of tech conferences is too enormous to track.)

* Spread word to peers! CallbackWomen (CallbackWomen) on Twitter The latest from CallbackWomen (@CallbackWomen). Code women who are tech speakers. Programming conferences, shout out with Call for Proposals when you're looking for code women to callback to it

item.content:encoded:
I'm speaking October 21st at Confident Coding III ("Everything Else You Need to Know"), an all-day web technology education conference for women and friends. We'll be at Microsoft's San Francisco offices at Market & Powell. Come join us for a fun day of learning about developer tools, automation, HTTP, the commandline, and more. Really useful stuff.

(Pssst. Women still earn 77% of what men do. Use discount code EQUALITY to register at 77% price.) Confident Coding III: Everything You need to know! A conference by women for women, encouraging women to be confident in their coding skills with the goal of increasing diversity in the development community

item.title: Joyent ending "Lifetime" hosting accounts.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I was TextDrive VC38, and wrote the service's first documentation.  In exchange, I and 1000 or so other seed investors were promised "lifetime hosting" for "as long as the company exists".  The company, now Joyent, this week announced that it's cancelling the contracts and giving just 80 days to migrate either to an expensive monthly account or to some other hosting company.  Either action requires significant investment of time to deal with transitioning all of one's sites.  Shoving customers off their servers is not nice to do on so little timeline and completely out of the blue.

Meanwhile over on Joyent's forums, Jason Hoffman -- who made those original contractual commitments as TextDrive's co-founder and is the current Joyent CEO axing them now -- has been making increasingly hostile snarks at those customer-investors.

Twitter and Joyent made their announcements on the same day.  What's up with companies deciding that the best business model for going forward is to show contempt for users and developers?  Crazy, yo. Ken McKinney originally shared this post: Joyent ending "Lifetime" hosting accounts.
Some years ago when Joyent (then TexDrive) was young and strapped for cash they offered "Lifetime" hosting accounts apparently by "lifetime" they meant until we get tired of supporting them....... 

Action Required:
Legacy Service End of Life

Dear Ken McKinney,

We've been analyzing customer usage of Joyent’s systems and noticed that you are one of the few customers that are still on our early products and have not migrated to our new platform, the Joyent Cloud. 

For many business reasons, including infrastructure performance, service quality and manageability, these early products are nearing their End of Life. We plan to sunset these services on October 31, 2012 and we'd like to walk you through a few options.

We understand this might be an inconvenience for you, but we have a plan and options to make this transition as easy as possible.  We’ve been developing more functionality on our new cloud infrastructure, the Joyent Cloud, for our customers who care about performance, resiliency and security.  Now’s the time to take advantage of all the new capabilities you don’t have today. Everyone that’s moved to our new cloud infrastructure has been pleased with the results.  

We appreciate and value you as one of Joyent's lifetime Shared Hosting customers. As this service is one of our earliest offerings, and has now run its course, your lifetime service will end on October 31, 2012. However, we believe that you will enjoy the new functionalities of the Joyent Cloud. To show you our appreciation, as one of Joyent's lifetime Shared Hosting customers, we'd like to offer you a free 512MB SmartMachine on the Joyent Cloud for one year. Use this promotional code to redeem the offer.

[Redacted]

Please review the Terms and Conditions for the Joyent Cloud One Year Free 512 MB Machine Promotion by visiting this link.

To find out more about the Joyent Cloud and your options, please follow this link to our migration center for additional details.


Sincerely,

Jason Hoffman
Founder and CTO
Joyent
jason@joyent.com

item.title: I'm presenting on "Schemas for the Real World" at Golden Gate Ruby Conference in September.
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I'm presenting on "Schemas for the Real World" at Golden Gate Ruby Conference in September.

App development, especially for social, challenges us to evaluate how to code for the complexity of modern life. Examples include the growing range of labels people ascribe to their important relationships, sexual orientation, and gender. Users are giving push-back to questions that carry ill-fitted assumptions.

Facebook, Google+, and developers in many other industries are grappling with these issues. The most resilient approaches will arise from an app's own foundations. We'll look at schemas' influence on product scope, UX, and analytics. Then we'll check out a range of approaches for bringing modern realities into any app's schema, views, and logic.

http://gogaruco.com/ The Golden Gate Ruby Conference 2012 Golden Gate Ruby Conference. September 14–15, 2012 San Francisco, CA at UCSF Mission Bay Register · Home · Speakers · Schedule · Sponsors · Team · Location. Explore new possibilities in the birth...

item.title: I get it, yes, Google I/O is coming to town and everyone's excited to piggyback their event to it. At...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
I get it, yes, Google I/O is coming to town and everyone's excited to piggyback their event to it.  At least a dozen excellent and genuinely substantial events I really would like to go to --  all competing for the same 2-3 hours of evening.  

Quit it.

You have something great to offer, and San Francisco can provide you with outstanding tech audiences every day of the year.  Scheduling on the 28th has unnecessarily forced us into the position of having to miss it.  At minimum, take note next time of how neglected the 27th, 29th (especially!), 30th are this year.

item.title: CREATIVE CURRENCY COLLABORATION WEEKEND BRIEF
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Good stuff. The crucial contextual that was left out of that post is the hackathon weekend's focus was on uses of technology to address socio-economic issues in the Mid-Market (aka "skid row") and Tenderloin neighborhoods.

The area is a center of homelessness, drug trade, and mental illness. It's also directly adjacent to the tech center neighhorhood, SOMA. The city has been very aggressively recruiting tech companies to expand into Mid-Market, as part of its gentrification and job expansion efforts. (Twitter and ZenDesk have been among the takers.) Creative Currency, its supporters such as Gray Area Foundation for the Arts and The Hub, and the projects spawned by the hackathon, are geeks being inspired to solve serious local problems. Robert Schwentker originally shared this post: CREATIVE CURRENCY COLLABORATION WEEKEND BRIEF

• This past weekend ~150 new economy thinkers, software engineers, designers & social entrepreneurs gathered at The Hub in San Francisco for the Creative Currency project. Over three days the initial 30+ ideas pitched resulted in a total of 12 compelling projects focused on innovating in the areas of economic development, housing, jobs, public health, education, payments & financial services. There were four winning teams provided with seed funding and mentorship.
• Top leaders from the SF City government, community agencies and tech companies, including Square & Kiva, were present to deliver keynote speeches, provide mentorship, judge projects & envision project outcomes.
• Project participants came from dozens of organizations including Visa, Square, Airbnb, Bernal Bucks, Code for America, Ashoka, EMC, LinkedIn, Kaiser, Google, Motorola, Stanford, Goodwill of Silicon Valley, Bay Area Timebank, & Kiva.

The Creative Currency judging team selected four teams for seed funding. Each team was awarded with $1,000, but must get back to the judges in two weeks time with their plans & requirements to further develop their projects. Judges will review the project plans and then determine which projects will obtain further investment. All teams were offered mentorship & introductions by the judging team. Teams will prepare for the next demo day in August.

The four winning teams, which had 5 to 13 participants each, are:

1) Team "TrustScore" created by Heidi Kim, Program Manager of Kiva Zip. TrustScore uses trust & recommendation as a creative form of currency that leverages informal networks to enable engagement in the formal economy. TrustScore is planned be an open source algorithm measuring a person's trustworthiness. Kiva Zip will most likely use TrustScore as a part of their peer-to-peer loan process -- to give lenders more confidence about borrowers.
http://jackdreilly.github.com/TrustScore & http://creative-currency.org/projects/trustscores

2) Team "Bridge" created a platform prototype that facilitates real time information exchange and action through multiple devices, including web, mobile phone, and kiosks; service providers can offer resources like beds, showers & meals, which users can peruse & reserve. Jay Nath of the City of SF expressed Bridge has a good market opportunity; that the city is looking to solve this problem and will be soon looking to purchase a software such as this, which team Bridge may be able to develop.
http://www.quietless.com/bridge/glide & http://creative-currency.org/projects/bridge

3) Team "Your SQFT" proposed repurposing vacant spaces in Mid-Market connecting property owners and landlords with entrepreneurs, startups, pop-up retail & local labor. Over the weekend the team interviewed local residents & business owners, and connected with key stakeholders such as property managers, renters, & community organizations focused on job placement. Their enthralling presentation was perhaps the best received, by both the audiences & the judges.
http://www.yoursqft.com & http://creative-currency.org/projects/yoursqft-space-for-people

4) Team “Refresh SF” designed a system predicated on the need to promote public health, build awareness of homelessness and encourage giving through an easy to donate system; there would be stations located throughout the Mid-Market which would provide wash rooms etc. Jay Nath said that the SF Department of Public Health would have interest in furthering this project; that such stations would have a significant social impact if implemented.
http://www.refreshsf.org & http://creative-currency.org/projects/refresh-sf

Other interesting projects included:

• Team "WorkToday" pitched matching day laborers to contractors via community based organizations, with rating systems, utilizing P2P escrow payments.
http://creative-currency.org/projects/worktoday & http://www.slideshare.net/davidcitor/worktoday

• Team “BACE Timebank is an existing organization - San Francisco Bay Area Community Exchange Timebank. Over the weekend they added an impressive SMS interface & prototyped UI/UX enhancements to their website.
http://creative-currency.org/projects/bace-timebank-oscurrency & http://bace.org

• Team “Lemonopoly” created an online/offline mobile game using actual lemons as currency to increase the local lemon trade.
http://lemonopoly.org & http://creative-currency.org/projects/lemonopoly

• Team “Financial Empowerment” conceived of a service design framework that will help increase financial literacy and empowerment for unbanked San Francisco residents, including use of prepaid cards.
http://creative-currency.org/projects/financial-empowerment

Creative Currency links:

Website:
http://creative-currency.org
Partners:
http://creative-currency.org/about/partners
Advisory Committee:
http://creative-currency.org/about/advisory-committee
Program Model:
http://creative-currency.org/about/program-model
Creative Currency Community Brief research paper:
http://creative-currency.org/community/community-brief
Initial collaboration project idea from participants:
http://connect.creative-currency.org/ideas
Team Project demoed:
http://creative-currency.org/projects
Twitter stream from the collaboration weekend: https://twitter.com/#!/search/realtime/cr8c Creative Currency | New tools for a new economy Creative Currency is a new model for community-driven innovation led by Gray Area Foundation for the Arts, Hub Bay Area, American Express, and The San Francisco Mayor's Office of Civic Innovation. The...

item.title: BAKING: Angel Fingers
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Off to a cookie swap/birthday party for a friend. My contribution is adapted from grandma’s perennial Christmas classic, Angel Fingers:


1/2 c. butter, softened
3 tbsp powdered sugar
1/2 tsp vanilla powder
1/4 tsp cinnamon
pinch of nutmeg
zest of 1 lemon, finely minced
1/8 tsb almond extract
1 c. cake flour
1 c. nuts, chopped finely (walnuts, almonds, pistaschios, or pecans are excellent)
lots of extra powdered sugar

Cream the butter until fluffy. Add sugar. Cream more.

Add vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, & almond extract. Cream more.

Slowly sprinkle about half the zest into the flour, stirring well to separate and coat. Gradually incorporate the flour/zest into the butter mixture.

Fold in nuts.

The mixture should be rather dry and crumbly. If necessary add a little more flour. (Don’t worry about being exact. The margin for error on the cake flour is pretty generous. I’ve had these cookies come out well even with nearly twice this much flour.)

Refrigerate 15-30 minutes to firm up the butter a bit. Preheat oven to 350.

Shape dough into crescents, roughly finger-sized. Place on greased baking sheet or parchment-lined sheet. Cook ~20mins just until set with light golden edges.

Cool briefly, about 5 minutes. While still warm, roll in bowl of powdered sugar to coat. Cool thoroughly before storing.

For a prettier finish, you can roll the cookies in powdered sugar a second time after they’ve completely cooled. (For an extra zing, you can incorporate the leftover zest into the sugar before doing the second coat!)

item.title: UPDATE: Thank you to the huge number of responders. We've secured a space! The workshop is continuing...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
UPDATE: Thank you to the huge number of responders. We've secured a space! The workshop is continuing as scheduled.

PREVIOUSLY:
Due to unforeseen circumstances, the location where Railsbridge
Outreach Workshop for Women was going to host this week's workshop has fallen through.

If we can't secure a new location by 3pm today (4/26), we'll have to
cancel the workshop. Not only will this be a bummer for us organizers
who have been toiling to put on the event, it'll really, really suck
for all the folks that have signed up for this event and put effort
into preparing for it.

Therefore, we are reaching out to you to see if your
company can accommodate 60-80 people Friday night and all day
Saturday. If your company in SOMA, Downtown, or Financial District can
accommodate us, please contact me before 3pm today/Thursday.



REQUIREMENTS:

Location - SOMA, Downtown, or Financial district; and walkable from
Muni, CalTrain, and BART.

Room Capacity - Railsbridge will have 40-50 students and 40-45
volunteers this weekend. We need 5 (or more, if available) breakout
rooms for them that are equipped with projector/adaptors, electrical
outlets, and guest wifi access.

Time needed - Friday 5pm -11pm (we'll hopefully be able to leave by
10, but need the buffer); Saturday 8:00am to 5:30pm (possibly as early
as 5pm).

Use of Facilities - Permission to use kitchen snacks/beverages would
be lovely, if the host company is amenable.

Sponsorship of food (nice to have; optional) - Food for Friday (pizza)
and Saturday (lunch, light breakfast). But Railsbridge can cover our
own food costs/arrangements if necessary.


Background info on Railsbridge can be found here:
http://railsbridge.org/
http://www.sfruby.info/events/60258772/

We hope one of you can come through for us. Thank you for your
support of Railsbridge!

item.title: The good: Mega Startup Weekend coming to Mountain View on April 21st! Mobile, gaming, robotics, woot...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The good: Mega Startup Weekend coming to Mountain View on April 21st! Mobile, gaming, robotics, woot! Make the products happen, y'all.

The bad: recruitment problem in the current lineup of organizers, speakers, mentors, judges. http://mega.startupweekend.org/ As best I can tell, just 2 of those 26 are women. For an event that's intended to foster new leadership and startup activity, of all things. (Yes, I've contacted them, and specifically asked what they're doing to fix this. Please add your voice too. http://mega.startupweekend.org/contact/ Organizers need to know how many people notice, and care about, such issues)

The ugly: the weekend is co-sponsored by the otherwise terrific Women 2.0. At the Women 2.0 Startup Weekend in December, women were everywhere: developers, entrepreneurs, speakers, mentors, organizers, target markets... There's no shortage of smart women to draw on. Women 2.0 and the other sponsors should have insisted that the organizers dig deeper into the well before announcing.

Who else is underrepresented at this event, by the way? Doesn't seem to me that blacks leaders in the field are visible either. C'mon, industry, we can and should do better.

EDIT: P.S. thanks go to Alaina for pointing out this, on a related note: http://snip.it/snips/113771 Mega Startup Weekend Startup Weekend is a 54 hour startup event that provides the networking, resources, and incentives for individuals and teams to go from idea to launch. Get connected with local developers, innovators ...

item.title: Taught frontend web development this Saturday at Railsbridge. It's such a pleasure getting to introduce...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Taught frontend web development this Saturday at Railsbridge. It's such a pleasure getting to introduce total n00bs to this stuff. They asked really insightful questions, which was exciting in itself.

For me, it was good to be challenged to consider these topics through beginners' eyes. Wow is the syntax of HTML vs CSS vs JavaScript tricky when they're all coming at a learner at once; their first encounter altogether with markup or coding. It's an ambitious day, which includes forays into git, bash commandline, SSH, and GitHub.

In the teachers' debriefing session afterward, we had a fascinating discussion about how the different class levels related to the curriculum's topics, and how to keep improving breadth and pacing. I hear one of the advanced classes worked on building a Twitter clone.

Just days left to finish prepping the Ruby on Rails backend Railsbridge workshop this Friday/Saturday (big thank you, +Twitter).

Oh, and we may have snazzy new Railsbridge sticker designs to hand out this weekend...

item.title: Seeking: even more women to become Railsbridge teachers, TAs, or installfest volunteers. You don't have...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Seeking: even more women to become Railsbridge teachers, TAs, or installfest volunteers. You don't have to be a "ninja", "guru", "superstar", or "expert". If you've been able to lean across the table and help a classmate or colleague troubleshoot now and then, you've got the chops to be a valuable contributor.

Bonuses: we train you beforehand, the curriculum is easy to present, we teach in teams (no worries about flying solo), we give you tons o' support during events, and you get a free drink at the after-party. Also, participants appreciate the heck out of us. You get to leave with a warm fuzzy glow of having brought excited newbies into the community. Neat!

Volunteer sign-ups for Twilio (HTML/CSS/JS) 4/20-4/21: http://www.sfruby.info/events/58304492/
Volunteer sign-ups for Twitter (Rails) 4/27-4/28: http://www.sfruby.info/events/60258512/ Volunteers Wanted: RailsBridge Workshop for Women #34 - April 27-28, 2012 Got some time and some RoR knowledge to share? Well, great! We need ya! We're looking for volunteer instructors and TAs. And when RSVP'ing, please indicate whether you'll be volunteering a...

item.title: Another good turnout for Women Who Code. This time with a Q&A with Guido van Rossum. He looked into ...
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Another good turnout for Women Who Code. This time with a Q&A with Guido van Rossum. He looked into the crowd and declared it the biggest gathering of female geeks he's ever seen. Which I have mixed feelings about. On the one hand, great that we've got this community of coders. On the other hand, why is it NOT commonplace to see such gatherings at a size comparable to this?

Answering a question about what he would do differently if he were starting Python from scratch, Guido got a big gasp from the audience when he suggested that one would be using curly braces instead of whitespace. Whoa. I wish.

It also turns out he's quite a fan of Haskell; enough to lovingly criticize the heck out of it.
